>From: "t_bommel" <t_bommel@...>
>
>hey everyone,
>
>i haven't been on in awhile but i just got started again working on
>my rabbit/wolf simulator. i was looking through christian's matlab
>code for the xor experiment and i noticed that he tracks the
>innovations by generation. however, since my simulator is designed to
>be continuous, there is no real "generations". i was wondering if
>anyone had any advice on how else to keep track of the innovations.
>maybe by year? i dont know. any help would be appreciated. thanks
>
>-timmy

I created a function UniqueID();  I call it.  It returns a number guaranteed 
to be unique within the run.  It does this by just incrementing a counter 
and returning the result.  I call that same function every time I need an 
ID.  Topology ID's, network ID's, Node ID's, you name it, it all gets its id 
from the same place.

And whenever a new one (topology, node) is created, I always look through a 
hash record to see if it is a duplicate of one created earlier.  If it is, I 
re-use the old ID, which makes things a lot easier.  You may or may not want 
to do that, but I suggest that it will simplify the search, if not the code. 
  And if you are coding in a language that makes the hash lookup easy, then 
it's even easy in the code.

-- John
